questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Meissner’s plexus is present in submucosa
Myentric plexus is present between inner circular and outer longitudinal muscle layer
Muscularis mucosa is associated with peristalsis
Villi are absent in large intestine

questions.solution:
Muscularis propria is associated with peristalsis and not muscularis mucosa.

Contraction of muscularis mucosa alters absorptive and secretive surface area.

Meissner’s plexus (submucosal plexus) is present in the submucosa.

The myenteric plexus (Auerbach plexus) is present between the inner circular and outer longitudinal muscle layer.

Villi are absent in the large intestine but present in the small intestine.

Layers of intestinal wall from outside to inside are as follows:

  • Serosa
  • The longitudinal smooth muscle layer
  • The circular smooth muscle layer
  • Submucosa
  • Mucosa

questions.text: Salivary amylase is inactivated by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Salivary amylase is inactivated by the low pH of the stomach. It is rapidly denatured at pH 4 (gastric pH is 1 to 3.5).

Salivary amylase is activated by chloride.

Salivary α amylase (Ptyalin):

  • Digests starch: cleaves internal α-1,4-glycosidic bonds in starch
  • Optimum pH: 7
  • Denatured at pH 4

Since a large portion of a meal often remains unmixed for a considerable length of time in the stomach, the salivary enzyme may account for the digestion of as much as 75% of the starch present before it is denatured by gastric acid.

Note: Even in the absence of salivary amylase, there is no defect in carbohydrate digestion because pancreatic amylase is sufficient to digest all of the ingested starch.

questions.text: Which of the following gland secretes lingual lipase?
questions.solution:
Lingual lipase is secreted by von Ebner’s gland.

von Ebner's gland is a serous salivary gland situated around circumvallate and foliate papillae in front of the terminal sulcus. 

Lingual lipase hydrolyse dietary lipid. The optimal pH is 3-6. Unlike pancreatic lipase, it is not inhibited by bile salts, medium-chain FA, and lecithin. Hence, it remains active through the stomach and into the intestine.

questions.text: Which of the following fluids have the highest daily secretion of potassium?
questions.solution:
The highest daily secretion of K+ is into the saliva.

In the process of formation of saliva, Na+ and Cl- are reabsorbed from the saliva, and K+ and HCO3- are secreted into the saliva.

Note: The highest concentration of K+ is in the rectal fluid.

questions.text: The secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland causing a patient to salivate, pass through which of the following ganglions?
questions.solution:
The secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland pass through the Otic ganglion.

Salivary secretion is almost entirely controlled by the parasympathetic nervous system. Volume is mainly mediated by parasympathetic stimulation while the composition of saliva (increased proteinaceous content) is slightly modified by sympathetic input.

The parasympathetic preganglionic fibers are delivered by the glossopharyngeal and facial nerves to otic and submandibular ganglion respectively.

questions.text: Rennin is present in_____
questions.solution:
Rennin is present in the gastric juice. It is also called chymosin.

It is a protein-digesting enzyme (endopeptidase) found in the stomach of newborn cows. It transforms (curdles) caseinogen into insoluble casein.

In humans and in some animals that lack rennin, milk is coagulated by the action of pepsin.

Note: Renin is produced by juxtaglomerular cells of the kidney, which hydrolyzes angiotensinogen to angiotensin I.

questions.text: A patient presents with anemia and achlorhydria. After evaluation, pernicious anemia is diagnosed. Damage to which of the following cells is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Pernicious anemia develops due to autoimmune damage to the parietal cells in gastric glands.

The parietal cells secrete both HCl and intrinsic factor. Therefore, when the parietal cells are destroyed, both achlorhydria, as well as pernicious anemia, develop.

Pernicious anemia occurs due to the deficiency of the intrinsic factor of Castle, which is important for the absorption of vitamin B12.

questions.text: Which of the following is secreted by the Goblet cells?
questions.solution:
Goblet cells secrete mucus. These cells are located on the surface of the crypts of Lieberkuhn and the villi of the small intestine.

Cells present in the crypts of Lieberkuhn:

  • Goblet cells (similar to surface cells of the stomach) - secrete mucus that acts as a lubricant and protects the intestinal surface
  • Epithelial cells - secrete succus entericus (intestinal secretion)
  • Paneth cells - secrete lysozymes and defensins (antibacterial substances)

questions.text: In the stomach, H+ ions are secreted in exchange for which of the following ions?
questions.solution:
H+ ions are secreted into the lumen of the stomach in exchange for K+ by the H+–K+ pump (H+, K+-ATPase).

Mechanism of HCl formation:

  • In the parietal cells, CO2 and H2O are converted to H+ and HCO3–, catalyzed by carbonic anhydrase.
  • H+ is secreted into the lumen of the stomach by the H+–K+ pump in exchange for K+.
  • HCO3– moves out of the cell into the bloodstream in exchange for Cl– (Cl––HCO3–exchange). This Cl– moves into the lumen of the stomach. 
  • H+ and Cl– combine to form HCl.

 

As HCO3– is added to the venous blood, the pH of the blood increases. This is called alkaline tide. Eventually, this HCO3– will be secreted in the pancreatic secretions to neutralize H+ in the small intestine.

Proton pump inhibitors inhibit H+–K+ pump.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease is found to have excess gastric secretion. All of the following are likely to increase the secretion, except:
questions.solution:
Gastric secretion is not increased by HCl. HCl decreases gastric secretion via a negative feedback mechanism.

Low pH due to HCl in the stomach inhibits gastrin secretion, which in turn, inhibits H+ secretion. Hence, the presence of HCl inhibits gastric secretion.

Stimuli that increase acid and gastrin secretion:

  • Distension of stomach
  • Peptides
  • Calcium
  • Alcohol and caffeine
  • Increased vagal discharge

Stimuli that decrease acid and gastrin secretion:

  • Gastric acid
  • Secretin family - secretin, glucagon, VIP, GIP
  • Somatostatin
  • CCK, Calcitonin
  • PGE2

Related Pearl: Stimuli for gastric secretion

Stimuli

Mechanism

Applied aspects

Vagal stimulation

Direct pathway

Vagus nerve innervates parietal cells and stimulates H+ secretion directly.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is Ach, the receptor on the parietal cells is muscarinic (M3)

The second messengers for CCK are IP3 and increased intracellular [Ca2+].

Atropine, a cholinergic muscarinic antagonist, inhibits H+ secretion by blocking the direct pathway, which uses ACh as a neurotransmitter. However, it does not block H+ secretion completely because it does not inhibit the indirect pathway, which uses GRP as a neurotransmitter

Indirect pathway

Vagus nerve innervates G cells and stimulates gastrin secretion, which then stimulates H+ secretion.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is GRP (not ACh).

Vagotomy eliminates both direct and indirect pathways.

Gastrin

Released in response to eating a meal (small peptides, distension of the stomach, vagal stimulation).

Stimulates H+ secretion by interacting with the cholecystokinin B (CCKB) receptor on the parietal cells.

The second messenger for gastrin on the parietal cell is IP3/Ca2+.

  

Histamine

Released from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells in the gastric mucosa and diffuses to the nearby parietal cells.

Stimulates H+ secretion by activating H2 receptors on the parietal cell membrane.

The H2 receptor is coupled to adenylyl cyclase via a Gs protein.

The second messenger for histamine is cAMP.

H2 receptor–blocking drugs, such as cimetidine, inhibit H+ secretion by blocking the stimulatory effect of histamine.

questions.text: A patient with recurrent abdominal pain is found to have multiple duodenal ulcers. After a detailed evaluation, he is diagnosed with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Stimulation of which of the following can inhibit gastric secretion in this patient?
questions.solution:
Gastric secretion is inhibited by somatostatin.

It inhibits gastric secretion via both direct and indirect pathways:

  • Direct pathway - somatostatin acts directly on the acid-producing parietal cells by binding to receptors on parietal cells that are coupled to adenylyl cyclase via a Gi protein. This inhibits adenylyl cyclase, and cAMP levels are reduced. In this way, somatostatin antagonizes the stimulatory effect of histamine on H+ secretion.
  • Indirect pathway - somatostatin inhibits the release of histamine and gastrin and thus decreasing H+ secretion indirectly.

Related Pearl: Factors inhibiting gastric secretion

Inhibiting factors

Mechanism

Low pH (< 3.0) in the stomach

When the pH of the stomach contents is <3.0, gastrin secretion is inhibited and, by negative feedback, inhibits further H+ secretion.

Somatostatin

Inhibits gastric H+ secretion by a direct pathway and an indirect pathway.

Direct pathway→ somatostatin binds to receptors on the parietal cell that are coupled to adenylyl cyclase via a Gi protein, thus inhibiting adenylyl cyclase and decreasing cAMP levels. In this pathway, somatostatin antagonizes the stimulatory action of histamine on H+ secretion.

Indirect pathway→ somatostatin inhibits release of histamine and gastrin, thus decreasing H+ secretion indirectly.

Prostaglandins

Inhibit gastric H+ secretion by activating a Gi protein, inhibiting adenylyl cyclase and decreasing cAMP levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the secretion from the exocrine pancreas?
questions.solution:
Pancreatic secretion is stimulated by cholecystokinin (CCK) and Ach. It is always isotonic.

It has virtually the same Na+ and K+ concentrations as in plasma. It is rich in several digestive enzymes like amylase, trypsin, chymotrypsin, lipase, elastase, etc.

questions.text: Bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice is secreted under the influence of which of the following stimulants?
questions.solution:
Bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice is secreted under the influence of secretin.

Secretin is secreted by the S cells of the duodenum. Its primary function is to promote the secretion of bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice by the ductal cells of the pancreas and duodenum. This secretion is poor in enzymes.

Other functions:

  • Augments the effects of CCK
  • Inhibits gastrin release
  • Decreases gastric acid secretion
  • Contraction of the pyloric sphincter
  • Exerts trophic effect on the pancreas

questions.text: Which among the following is the most alkaline secretion?
questions.solution:
The most alkaline secretion is Brunner’s gland secretion with a pH of 8.0 – 8.9.  

Brunner’s gland is located in the first few centimeters of the duodenal wall. It secretes large amounts of alkaline mucus in response to tactile stimuli on the duodenal mucosa, vagal stimulation, and GI hormones, especially secretin. It is inhibited by sympathetic stimulation.

The function of the mucus secreted by Brunner’s glands is to protect the duodenal wall from digestion by the highly acidic gastric juice emptying from the stomach.

Note: The second most alkaline secretion in the GI tract is the pancreatic juice.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent choleretic?
questions.solution:
Bile salts (chemical choleretic) are the most potent choleretics.

Any substance that increases bile secretion is called a choleretic. Bile secretion may be increased by chemical (bile salts), hormonal (Secretin), and neural (vagal stimulation) mechanisms.

Note: Cholagogues cause contraction of the gallbladder. Eg. CCK

questions.text: Primary bile acids are synthesized from_____
questions.solution:
Primary bile acids are synthesized from cholesterol by hepatocytes.

Bile contains bile acids, bile salts, bile pigments, phospholipids, water, and electrolytes. It is secreted by the liver and concentrated in the gall bladder.

Two primary bile acids (cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid) are synthesized from cholesterol by hepatocytes. When these primary bile acids are secreted into the lumen of the intestine, a portion of each is converted to secondary bile acids (deoxycholic acid and lithocholic acid) by bacteria.

The liver conjugates primary and secondary bile acids with glycine or taurine to their respective bile salts. Ex: Glycocholic acid, Taurodeoxycholic acid.

Rate of bile secretion is 30 - 60 mL/hour (500 - 1000 mL/day). 

Note: Bile has no digestive enzymes.

questions.text: Enterohepatic circulation is necessary for the secretion of______
questions.solution:
Enterohepatic circulation is necessary for the secretion of bile salts.

The enterohepatic circulation of bile salts is the recycling of bile salts between the small intestine (terminal ileum) and the liver by means of the portal vein. It occurs 6-8 times a day.

The recirculation of bile salts to the liver reduces the demand to synthesize new bile salts.

questions.text: Which of the following does not belong to the secretin family?
questions.solution:
CCK (Cholecystokinin) belongs to the gastrin family, not the secretin family.

Classification of GI hormones based on structure and function:

  • Gastrin family - Gastrin, Cholecystokinin
  • Secretin family - Secretin, Glucagon, VIP, GIP
  • Others - Motilin, Ghrelin, Somatostatin, etc

questions.text: A patient underwent resection of the gastric antrum. A few weeks later, endoscopy revealed atrophy of the gastric mucosa. Serum levels of gastrin were found to be decreased. Which of the following is true regarding this GI hormone?
questions.solution:
Gastrin is a peptide hormone. 

It is secreted by the G cells of the gastric mucosa present in the antrum of the stomach, primarily during the gastric phase of gastric acid secretion.

It causes gastric secretion at 1000-1500 mL/day. Its primary stimulus is gastric distension.

Primary functions of Gastrin:

  • Gastric acid (HCl) secretion
  • Pepsin secretion
  • Trophic action on the gastric mucosa

Other functions:

  • Stimulates gastric motility
  • Prevents gastroesophageal reflux by contraction of LES

Conditions associated with increased gastrin secretions (Ex: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome), will cause an increase in H+ secretion and hypertrophy of the gastric mucosa.

Conditions associated with reduced gastrin secretion (Ex: Resection of the gastric antrum), will cause a decrease in H+ secretion and atrophy of the gastric mucosa.

Related Pearl: Stimuli that affect gastrin secretion

Stimuli that increase gastrin secretion

  • Luminal - Peptides and amino acids
  • Neural - Increased vagal discharge via GRP
  • Bloodborne
    • Ca 2+
    • Epinephrine

Stimuli that inhibit gastrin secretion

  • Luminal
    • Acid
    • Somatostatin 
  • Bloodborne- Secretin, GIP, VIP, glucagon, calcitonin

questions.text: What is the effect of cholecystokinin on GIT?
questions.solution:
Cholecystokinin (CCK) inhibits gastric emptying. 

It is secreted by the I cells of the duodenal and jejunal mucosa in response to monoglycerides, fatty acids, and amino acids.

Primary functions:

  • Stimulation of pancreatic enzyme secretion
  • Contraction of the gallbladder
  • Relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi

Other functions:

  • Augmentation of the action of secretin in producing alkaline (bicarbonate rich) pancreatic juice
  • Inhibition of gastric emptying
  • Trophic (growth) effect on the exocrine pancreas
  • Increases the synthesis of enterokinase
  • It enhances the motility of the small intestine and colon
  • Along with secretin, it augments the contraction of the pyloric sphincter and thus preventing the reflux of duodenal contents into the stomach
  • It promotes satiety

questions.text: Liver synthesizes all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Immunoglobulins are not synthesized by the liver. They are produced by plasma cells.

questions.text: How much is the daily secretion of gastric juice?
questions.solution:
Daily secretion of gastric juice is between 1500-2000 mL.

Note: This is a controversial question- Daily secretion of gastric juice is 

  • 1500 mL according to Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology,13th edition, Page no: 819
  • 2500 mL according to Ganong's Review Of Medical Physiology - 25th Edition, Page no:464

Choose 2500 mL if given in the options. If not, choose within the range of 1500-2500 mL.
